awd_titl_txt: Fundamental principles, limits, and function of ultrafast motion in single cell organisms
awd_abstract_narration:
Contrary to popular notion, the fastest movements in biology are not exhibited by large, multicellular animals such as a sprinting cheetahs or Usain Bolt, but by obscure, tiny microscopic single cell organisms. How a seemingly simple cell may generate extraordinary power and speed, without muscles, remains an open question. To address this critical knowledge gap, this project will study an extreme unicellular organism (Spirostomum ambiguum) that harnesses poorly understood molecular motors, springs and latches to achieve some of the fastest and most powerful movements in nature. In addition to advancing our knowledge of cell biology, insights from this project holds potential for a breakthrough in nanoscale engineering, including design of powerful micro-robots. The PI will involve young scientists across all levels in cell biophysics research including K-12, undergraduate and under-represented minority students in the Atlanta area. The PI will also host high-school summer interns in partnership with Lambert High School. Research findings and scientific discoveries will be shared with the broader public through popular media outlets including, popular media, YouTube, and the local Atlanta Science Festival. 

Spirostomum is a relatively large protozoan, which moves via a controllable-triggered myoneme.  It is an excellent model system to understand fundamental questions of achieving extraordinary power amplification at the scale of a single cell. The proposed research will integrate tools and techniques from biology, physics and mathematics to develop a multi-scale framework that establishes: i) the governing principles for force generation through calcium-based supramolecular protein networks (i.e., myonemes); ii) the physical limits on speed imposed by both cellular material properties and viscous energetic dissipation to environment; and iii), collective hydrodynamic communication and sensing through ultra fast group contractions in single cells.
This project is jointly funded by Molecular and Cellular Biosciences and the Physics of Living Systems

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
During the course of our NSF project titled "Fundamental Principles, Limits, and Function of Ultrafast Motion in Single-Cell Organisms" (Federal Award ID: 1817334), we concentrated on the study of Spirostomum ambiguum, a protozoan known for its ultrafast motions facilitated by a myoneme-based contractile apparatus. This mechanism, driven by Ca²⁺ ions, operates on a different principle compared to the more extensively studied ATP-driven actomyosin contraction found in other organisms. Our endeavor was to understand and model the dynamical properties of this Ca²⁺-driven contraction, which until now remained largely elusive.

We developed a minimal continuum model that semiquantitatively explains the experimental measurements observed in Spirostomum, uncovering distinct operating regimes of myoneme-based contraction. The dynamics were found to rely on three timescales representing chemical driving, material stiffness, and viscous drag. This study not only sheds light on the mechanochemical force generation and protozoan evolution but also opens avenues in the field of synthetic biology, potentially guiding the design of ultrafast bioengineered systems such as active synthetic cells.

A significant discovery during this project was the phenomenon of ‘hydrodynamic trigger waves’ in cellular communities of Spirostomum ambiguum. These waves propagate hundreds of times faster than their swimming speed, functioning somewhat like a chain reaction. The contraction of a single cell can generate long-ranged vortex flows that can trigger neighboring cells, a communication facilitated through hydrodynamic signals. This finding suggests a sophisticated level of organization in cellular communities, influencing behavior and potentially playing a role in survival strategies such as predator repulsion or prey immobilization.

The project fostered the growth and development of a diverse cohort of budding scientists and researchers at various stages in their educational journey, including high school students advancing to prestigious undergraduate programs, undergraduates securing opportunities at renowned institutions for further studies, and postdocs transitioning into faculty positions at R1 research universities, thereby nurturing the next generation of leaders in the field.

Our project embraced a strong commitment to educational outreach. We engaged in the training of high school science teachers and high school students, enhancing their understanding of protozoan biomechanics and fostering a deeper appreciation for this field in the next generation of learners. Moreover, we mentored high school students in the development of affordable STEM education tools, including a low-cost tracking microscope and synthetic biology hardware. This initiative aimed to foster innovation and accessibility in the field, encouraging young minds to approach science with a hands-on, inventive spirit.

We also developed multi-lingual comics to convey the fascinating dynamics of protozoan life to a broader audience. This initiative was designed to bridge the gap between complex scientific concepts and the general public, offering an engaging and accessible medium to share the wonders of biological research.
